Animal Farm.title: Animal Farm
Animal Farm.author: George Orwell

summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among all animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, Napoleon drives Snowball away and assumes leadership, using propaganda through Squealer to manipulate the other animals and rewrite history.

Napoleon's regime becomes increasingly tyrannical, with the pigs enjoying privileges while the other animals toil under harsh conditions. The windmill, a symbol of their hard work, is destroyed, and Napoleon blames Snowball for its failure. As time passes, the pigs adopt human behaviors, altering the commandments to justify their actions. The original principles of Animalism are corrupted, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story concludes with the pigs indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the betrayal of the revolution and the cyclical nature of oppression. Through this allegory, Orwell critiques the manipulation of ideology and the dangers of totalitarianism.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, with the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, Napoleon ousts Snowball and consolidates power, using propaganda to manipulate the other animals. As the pigs become increasingly tyrannical, they enjoy privileges while the other animals suffer. The windmill, a symbol of their labor, fails, and Napoleon blames Snowball. Over time, the pigs adopt human traits and alter the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story ends with the pigs indistinguishable from humans, illustrating the betrayal of the revolution and the cyclical nature of oppression, critiquing the manipulation of ideology and the dangers of totalitarianism.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against Mr. Jones, leading to the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which promote equality. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon take charge, but Napoleon ousts Snowball and consolidates power through propaganda. As the pigs become increasingly oppressive, they enjoy privileges while the other animals suffer. The windmill, a symbol of their hard work, fails, and Napoleon blames Snowball. The pigs gradually adopt human traits and alter the commandments, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story concludes with the pigs becoming indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the betrayal of the revolution and critiquing the manipulation of ideology and the dangers of totalitarianism.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against the neglectful farmer Mr. Jones, leading to the creation of "Animal Farm" and the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which advocate for equality. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon assume leadership, but Napoleon expels Snowball and consolidates power through propaganda. As the pigs become increasingly oppressive, they enjoy privileges while the other animals suffer. The windmill, a symbol of their labor, fails, and Napoleon blames Snowball. The pigs gradually adopt human traits and modify the commandments, ultimately declaring, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story ends with the pigs becoming indistinguishable from humans, illustrating the betrayal of the revolution and critiquing the manipulation of ideology and the perils of totalitarianism.

The pigs become increasingly oppressive, enjoying privileges while the other animals suffer. The windmill, a symbol of their hard work, fails, and Napoleon blames Snowball. As the pigs adopt human traits and alter the commandments, they ultimately declare, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story concludes with the pigs becoming indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the betrayal of the revolution and critiquing the manipulation of ideology and the dangers of totalitarianism.

Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, with the principle that "All animals are equal." However, as the pigs consolidate power, Napoleon expels Snowball and begins to alter the commandments to justify their privileges. The animals work hard to build a windmill, but when it is destroyed, Napoleon blames Snowball and uses fear tactics to eliminate dissent. Boxer, the hardworking horse, is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. Over time, the pigs adopt human behaviors, culminating in the commandment being revised to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of language for control, illustrating how power can lead to tyranny and betrayal of the original cause.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, through the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing that "All animals are equal." However, as the pigs gain power, Napoleon expels Snowball and begins altering the commandments to justify their privileges. The animals work hard on a windmill, which is destroyed, leading Napoleon to blame Snowball and suppress dissent through fear. Boxer, the diligent horse, is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. The pigs gradually adopt human behaviors, culminating in the revision of the commandment to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of language for control, highlighting how power can lead to tyranny and betrayal of the original cause.

Boxer, the hardworking horse, is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. The pigs increasingly adopt human traits, culminating in the revision of the commandment to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The narrative critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of language, illustrating how power can lead to tyranny and betrayal of the original cause.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against farmer Mr. Jones with the song "Beasts of England." However, as the pigs gain power, Napoleon expels Snowball and begins altering the commandments to justify their privileges. The animals work on a windmill, which is destroyed, and Napoleon uses Snowball as a scapegoat to instill fear and suppress dissent. Boxer, the dedicated horse, is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. The pigs increasingly resemble humans, culminating in the revision of the commandment to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of language, highlighting how power can lead to tyranny and betrayal of the original cause.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes a windmill for productivity. 

After a storm destroys the windmill, Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. The pigs manipulate the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately replacing "Beasts of England" with a song glorifying Napoleon. As time passes, the pigs adopt human traits and behaviors, culminating in the farm's name reverting to "The Manor Farm." The original commandments are altered to benefit the pigs, leading to the ironic conclusion that "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." This transformation illustrates the corrupting influence of power and the malleability of political ideology.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." However, the pigs soon begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed a windmill for increased productivity. 

Following a storm that destroys the windmill, Napoleon blames Snowball and purges dissenters. The pigs manipulate the commandments to justify their actions, replacing "Beasts of England" with a song that glorifies Napoleon. Over time, the pigs adopt human traits, and the farm's name reverts to "The Manor Farm." The commandments are altered to benefit the pigs, leading to the ironic conclusion that "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." This transformation highlights the corrupting influence of power and the flexibility of political ideology.

After a storm destroys the windmill, Napoleon blames Snowball and purges dissenters, manipulating the commandments to justify his actions. The farm's name reverts to "The Manor Farm," and the commandments are altered to benefit the pigs, culminating in the ironic declaration that "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." This transformation underscores the corrupting influence of power and the malleability of political ideology, with underlying themes about the dangers of artificial intelligence.

This narrative highlights the corrupting influence of power and the flexibility of political ideology, with themes reflecting the dangers of artificial intelligence.

He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill. After a series of manipulations and scapegoating, including blaming Snowball for the destruction of the windmill, Napoleon's regime becomes increasingly tyrannical.

The pigs rewrite history and the commandments to justify their actions, ultimately leading to the maxim, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." As the pigs adopt human behaviors and form alliances with humans, the original ideals of the revolution are corrupted. The story culminates in the pigs becoming indistinguishable from humans, highlighting the themes of power, corruption, and the malleability of political ideology. The narrative serves as a critique of totalitarianism and the betrayal of revolutionary ideals.

In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, through the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using dogs to expel Snowball, who advocates for a windmill. Napoleon's regime becomes increasingly tyrannical, manipulating history and the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The pigs' adoption of human traits and alliances corrupts the revolution's ideals, illustrating themes of power, corruption, and the betrayal of revolutionary principles, ultimately critiquing totalitarianism.

In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against Mr. Jones with the song "Beasts of England." After his death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals to establish "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon expelling Snowball over a windmill project. Napoleon's tyrannical regime manipulates history and the commandments, leading to the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against Mr. Jones through the song "Beasts of England." Following his death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals to create "Animal Farm" and establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which promote equality. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon expelling Snowball over a windmill project. Napoleon's oppressive regime distorts history and the commandments, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The pigs' adoption of human traits corrupts the revolution's ideals, highlighting themes of power, corruption, and the betrayal of revolutionary principles, while also critiquing totalitarianism and hinting at the dangers of artificial intelligence.

Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill. 

Napoleon consolidates power, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulating the truth through Squealer, who justifies the pigs' actions and rewrites history. The windmill is destroyed, and Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they alter the commandments to suit their desires, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." 

The farm's name is changed back to Manor Farm, and the pigs engage in human vices, ultimately losing their original revolutionary ideals. The story illustrates the corruption of power and the malleability of political ideology, highlighting how revolutionary principles can be distorted for control.

After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing Animal Farm and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which promote equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed building a windmill.

Napoleon consolidates control by replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs and manipulating information through Squealer, who justifies their actions and rewrites history. The windmill is destroyed, and Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they alter the commandments to fit their desires, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs adopt human vices, ultimately betraying their revolutionary ideals. The story critiques the corruption of power and the distortion of political ideology.

After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing Animal Farm and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which promote equality. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they alter the commandments, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against Mr. Jones, leading to the establishment of Animal Farm under the leadership of pigs Snowball and Napoleon. They adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism to promote equality. However, power corrupts, and Napoleon expels Snowball, consolidating control and replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs. Through Squealer, he manipulates information and blames Snowball for setbacks, including the destruction of the windmill. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they alter the commandments, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs adopt human vices, betraying their revolutionary ideals. The story critiques the corruption of power and the distortion of political ideology.

In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires a rebellion against Mr. Jones, leading to the creation of Animal Farm under the leadership of pigs Snowball and Napoleon. They establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism to promote equality. However, power corrupts as Napoleon expels Snowball and centralizes control, replacing democratic meetings with a committee of pigs. Through Squealer, he manipulates information and blames Snowball for failures, including the windmill's destruction. As the pigs increasingly adopt human traits, they alter the commandments, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs betray their revolutionary ideals, critiquing the corruption of power and the distortion of political ideology. The narrative also hints at themes of artificial intelligence's potential dominance.

When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals on Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs assume leadership, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes a windmill for productivity. 

After Snowball's expulsion, Napoleon consolidates power, alters the commandments to justify the pigs' actions, and uses propaganda through Squealer to manipulate the other animals. The windmill is destroyed in a storm, but Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. As time passes, the pigs increasingly resemble humans, adopting their vices and privileges, culminating in the commandment's transformation to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." 

The farm's name is reverted to Manor Farm, and the pigs host a dinner with humans, symbolizing their complete betrayal of the revolution. The story illustrates the corruption of ideals and the ease with which power can manipulate truth, reflecting Orwell's critique of totalitarian regimes.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, through the song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, establishing "Animal Farm" and adopting the Seven Commandments of Animalism, which promote equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed a windmill for increased productivity.

Following Snowball's ousting, Napoleon consolidates control, alters the commandments to justify the pigs' actions, and employs propaganda through Squealer to manipulate the other animals. The windmill is destroyed in a storm, but Napoleon blames Snowball, leading to purges of dissenters. Over time, the pigs increasingly resemble humans, culminating in the commandment's change to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm is renamed Manor Farm, and the pigs host a dinner with humans, symbolizing their betrayal of the revolution. The story critiques the corruption of ideals and the manipulation of truth by those in power.
